entry.title: Re: Query on Replenishment strategy in storage type
entry.content: Hi Lakshmi, Could you please help clarify my understanding? In my system, I set the maximum quantity to 200. Initially, the replenishment bin had 0 stock. When I triggered replenishment, the system created a warehouse request for 200 units, and I did not select the “Immediate WT Creation” option. Later, I manually put away 50 units into the replenishment bin. Currently, it does not seem to behave as expected.

entry.title: Re: No prices could be determined for object KLA000DOMI L...
entry.content:
Good day @AngelT 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, when you use routing in public cloud and the system cannot find matching activity prices for the work center or activity type, it often delivers that error message.

I recommend you check if:

  1. Your work center has a cost center and formular for your activity calculation.
  2. You have assigned your activity type to that cost center.
  3. Make sure you confirm that your activity price is maintained in Manage Cost Rates-Plan for the correct ledger or year.
  4. Make sure your UOM match between routing and activity price.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Cost Center Activity Type, Cost Allocation to Cost Centers, Cost Center Activity Cost Rate Planning, Linking of Cost Centers and Business Processes

From your screenshot I can see that your routing uses MIN, while you have maintained your activity price in H. This prevents the system from determining a valid rate. Ensure to align them and it should resolve the issue.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to connect SAP Solution Manager with Third party...
entry.content:
SAP Solution Manager can be connected to external service desk tools via the Webservice API, as per KBA 2556872. The KBA directs you to the Webservice API technical guide, as well as some additional documentation. The steps in the Webservice API technical guide will guide you to complete the integration fully.

If you wish for the external service desk content to be automatically synched with the SAP Solution Manager ITSM Incidents, KBA 2936030 will help you to achieve this by setting flag "Keep in sync" for the system in ICTCONF.

entry.title: How to sort a Dynamic Table in Adobe Forms using Form-Level Scripting (JavaScript/FormCalc)
entry.content:
Hello Everybody, 

I have an Adobe Form requirement to sort a dynamic data table row printing on the form based on the Material field. Currently, this data is populating without any sorting as it is fetched from the Form Provider Gateway Service. 

There is no scope to do this sorting in the backend using any enhancements. The only option is to sort the data at Adobe level using scripting.

I have tried scripting at the Event 'Form: Ready' for the data row  (Row1) of my Table and referred to blogs but this script isn't working. Below is the hierarchy of my form layout and the current script I am trying: 

 

FormCalc script I am trying: 

var tbl = "$._Row1" // Table row
var i = 0 // Source row
var j = 0 // Compared row
var tblLength = xfa.resolveNode( tbl ).all.length // Number of rows
var source // Source concatenated fields to compare
var destination // Compare to concatenated fields
// *** Loop from the first row
for i = 0 upto tblLength - 1 do
  // *** Compare with the subsequence rows
  for j = i + 1 upto tblLength -1 do
    source       = xfa.resolveNode( tbl )[ i ].Itm_no    // Concatenate fields source to compare
    destination  = xfa.resolveNode( tbl )[ j ].Itm_no    // Concatenate fields to compare with
    if ( source > destination ) then
      xfa.resolveNode( tbl).instanceManager.moveInstance( j, i )
    endif
  endfor // j
endfor // i

 

JavaScript Code I tried: 

(function(){  
    var rows = this.resolveNodes("Row1[*]");  
    var rowCount = rows.length;       
    if (rowCount <= 1) return;       
    // Bubble sort    
    for (var i = 0; i < rowCount - 1; i++) {         
       for (var j = 0; j < rowCount - i - 1; j++) {        
            var row1 = rows.item(j);            
            var row2 = rows.item(j + 1);                          
            var mat1 = row1.Itm_no.rawValue || "";             
            var mat2 = row2.Itm_no.rawValue || "";                          
            // Compare and swap if needed             
            if (mat1 > mat2) {                
             // Swap all field values                
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Itm_no");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Pro_desc");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "qty_ucomm");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Guid_pric");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Discount");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Unit_price");   
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Net_amt");       
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Vat_Rate");     
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "VAT_amt");              
              }         }     }         

  function swapFieldValues(row1, row2, fieldName) {         
  var field1 = row1.resolveNode(fieldName);         
  var field2 = row2.resolveNode(fieldName);                  
  if (field1 && field2) {             
  var temp = field1.rawValue;             
  field1.rawValue = field2.rawValue;             
  field2.rawValue = temp;         }    

}

}

) ();

Any inputs/suggestions are appreciated. Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Adobe Form: Subform in every page
entry.content:
Good day @Dario_Bondoni 

Thank you for your question.

The best practice is to convert header subform into a table header row. Below is the reason.

In summary, due to the clean-core principle in public cloud, the system does not allow you to place data-bound subforms in Master Pages. That is the reasons why you get printing errors while trying to place delivery note fields there.

However, as mentioned above, you can workaround this by placing the header subform inside the same flowed parent as the item table or convert the header into a table header row. Which means your header must be flowed or semi-flowed and not fully positioned. The table header rows will automatically repeat on every page and will work in all overflow scenarios.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

SAP Forms Service by Adobe, Editing the Form Layout Using Adobe LifeCycle Designer

Check out this Blog: How to restrict a logo placed in master page of adobe form to only first page

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom Adobe Form How to Print 7 Outputs with Differe...
entry.content:
Good day @Yash_Rudraksha 

Thank you for your question.

Just to add to the answer you got from @HenrikeGrtecke 

Yes, public cloud allows you to print seven different invoice copies but not by triggering seven printouts. The Output Management in public cloud allows only one print form per invoice.

However, you can achieve your requirement by implementing the logic inside the Adobe Form. You should create a repeated subform that contains the full invoice layout and repeat it seven times. Consider using a small script to assign the correct label for each copy (Original, Duplicate, Triplicate, Extra Copy). The result will be a single PDF containing seven print copies with your desired headers.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

SAP Forms Service by Adobe & Restrictions.

Similar question: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/repeating-multiple-header-rows-of-table-in-subsequent-pages/qaa-p/4750150#M1809258

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Schedule Job for Mass changes to purchase orders
entry.content:
Good day @KeLaw 

Thank you for your question.

Due to the public cloud’s clean-core principle, scheduling recurring mass-change jobs when you use the Mass Changes to Purchase Orders app is not permitted. The app only supports manual, one-time executions.

You can use the Build Process Automation if your business requires recurring PO updates. This will enable you to call the official purchase order OData API (only for fields that API supports). Otherwise, you will have to continue triggering mass-changes manually.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

API for Purchase Order, Configure Automation Capabilities Prerequisites, Configuring the SAP Build Process Automation Integration

You may consider lend your vote to that improvement requirement to further highlight the need. Potentially SAP might consider a solution.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Story of SAP Materials Management Module in Implementation Projects
entry.content:
SAP MM

 SAP Materials Management is filled with many information from the theoretical part, but going to the practical part in the implementation projects. Here we are having another side from the story. When there is a SAP MM module required in an implementation projects, that doesn't mean that everything in MM module in the theoretical part is required to be implemented, but we just take from the MM module what is required to fulfill the business need. Some implementations could have some cycles from SAP MM as optional, that are not required to be part of the project. It is about adapting the MM module to the business need. Here is a big reason that even after consultants make a end to end cycle they still haven't covered all the MM module aspects. At this point they have covered the basic MM module standards and any new added part due to a specific business need for a client requirement. 

SAP Materials Management is related to all the process for the materials from the start of having a business need triggered by a certain material requirement, that will lead to the procurement decision that will require the SAP MM module to facilitate the full process. Starting that any client who require to procure material need the support of MM module to handle the full process in a smooth and efficient way. This material passes by the full procurement process until they are in the warehouse, where the client have a full control on this material either by consumption, selling them or even sending them to a customer. Materials Management in implementation projects should be implemented in a way that make the business make the full procurement cycle matching their old processes they used to make, just with some advancements and new easier ways of handling and reporting.

SAP Materials Management starts by the normal procure 2 pay process. The business says "We want to buy these materials or services for a specific reasons". They start contacting the procurement department about this requirement. If there is no a planning module that determine the quantity required. They can determine the quantity based on their historical data or just the materials that have been consumed from the warehouses and it is needed to be refilled. Now quantity is determined at this point they need to start creating an internal request to purchase these materials and in MM module it is called the purchase requisition screen. It is a screen that translates this step in the procurement by adding all the required data about the material and assigning a source of supply. This source of supply can be general supplier, fixed supplier and even one time supplier. SAP helps clients to determine the best suppliers through "Request for Quotation -> Quotation -> Price Comparison". These steps help to select the supplier that matches the client needs from the quantity and the value perspective.

Until that point we need to ask one question, where is the data of the material and suppliers are coming. That is why SAP is providing a master data, which means a constant long term source of data that can feed the full transactions to have a successful SAP procurement cycle. Master data should contain all the data regarding the material such as name, description, weight, unit of measure, price control and profit center. The supplier must contain the required data for it's name, address, bank account and roles such as supplier or customer. Feeding SAP with all the required clear data in the master data will ensure a successful accurate SAP MM procure 2 pay cycle. As part of master data SAP is providing some kind of container that is called purchasing info record this container contain both information from the vendor master and the material master. It helps to retrieve data in a smooth way in the procurement process.

Having everything prepared from the material and supplier. Here the time came to send the formal request to the vendor to send the materials to our warehouses. This step is translated in SAP as the purchase order screen. In this screen we add all the details about this purchase of the materials. Most of the data can be imported from the purchase requisition by referencing this purchase order to that purchase requisition. In PO (Purchase Order) client can add the supplier Org. structure (Plant & Storage Location). Also one or multiple materials can be added with all the required pricing conditions, quantity, delivery date, currency and unit of measure. It could be also added as a scheduled materials, where these materials can be delivered on a planned sequential dates like some can come at day 12 other can come at day 20 other can come at day 30. It is like you are dividing the delivery of these materials on multiple days.

This purchase order should contain all the required data as it will be sent to the vendor. Here we are going to another point with a question "Shall the user just create the purchase order, save it and send it directly ?". There should be kind of release strategy, approval strategy, review strategy and even a controlled way over this critical step. That is why SAP provide some kind of workflow that help purchase order to pass by multiple approval levels only the individuals users in every approval level can approve this purchase order. If a purchase order have four approval levels this means that the purchase order is being reviewed four times before it is being released to the vendor. Release strategy is a way of having a confidence that this purchase order is being released in the correct way that matches the business requirements. Same release strategy can be on the purchase requisition and purchase order.

After the vendor receive the purchase order now the vendor is aware with the material that is required to be delivered in quantity, delivery date and it's price. Now the vendor can start sending the materials in a confident clear way to the warehouses of the client. Once the materials are received to the client location. They are not directly placed in the warehouse they should be reviewed for quality and quantity. That is why SAP is providing three stock types: unrestricted stock, quality inspection stock and blocked stock. According to the state of the materials it is placed in this type of stock. SAP is providing a way called transfer posting to be able to transfer these materials on the system level as on ground level. After the materials are inspected and they passed the quality test. They start placing this materials in the warehouse, so same activity should be mapped on the system. Here the goods receipt step comes into the picture. 

Client starts creating a goods receipt with respect to the purchase order. It is translated that if the quantity increased in the warehouses it should increase on the system level. After creating the goods receipt by entering the data from the reference purchase order and adding all the required data of plant and storage location that has received this material. The stock will increase in the system and this will appear in SAP stock reports. SAP understand the stock movements through movement types. Every stock movement has a specific movement type that is translated to an action. Selecting the correct movement type will make the SAP system understand that this delivery caused an increase in the stock. After stock is fully recieved it's time to pay the vendor through the invoice. At this point invoice is created through a screen in SAP referencing the Purchase order and Goods Receipt to ensure the full accuracy which is being called 3-way match. After the invoice is created and verified through the accounting documents. Finance now can pay the vendor for this materials delivery.

In this article we spoke on a MM cycle from the business level and how it is translated to the system level. MM module is a large core module with many dependencies and many criteria. Making one end to end implementation won't make you cover all the SAP MM module parts. It differs according the business need. MM module is a very interesting module because it deals with a part of the business very critical related to the supply chain. Keep exploring the SAP MM module and would be glad if you leave comment on my article.

 SAP Supply Chain Management  MM (Materials Management)

entry.title: Harmonizing tracking across SAP Business Network for Logistics
entry.content:
With SAP Business Network for Logistics release 2511, SAP harmonizes freight execution tracking across SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (FC) and SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace (GTT). This article outlines the new, harmonized tracking experience and the role of the shared Web UI for manual event reporting—the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app —which provides a consistent look for role-appropriate views by shippers and carriers, and ties events to a central tracking table accessible from both Freight Collaboration (FC) and Global Track and Trace (GTT).

This unification consolidates information shared across FC, Dock Appointment Scheduling, and GTT. As part of the product roadmap, the legacy apps ‘Track Freight Movement’ for FC shippers and ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ for FC carriers are planned for deprecation in May 2026. GTT solution owners gain an additional reporting channel, enabling data contributors to report events via the Web UI.

Alongside the shared event-reporting application, we refined the tracking scenarios in FC and GTT.

This blog is structured as follows:

  • Introducing the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app
  • Use-case differentiation for event tracking in FC and GTT
  • Next steps for shippers / solution owners
    • FC shippers using basic tracking
    • GTT solution owners receiving tracking information through B2B connectivity with data contributors
    • GTT solution owners planning to request event reporting via Web UI from some data contributors and C shippers wanting to leverage
  • Next steps for carriers / data contributors
    • Carriers using the legacy ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ app
    • Carriers or data contributors connecting via API or EDI
    • Carriers newly requested by their shipper customers to report events via the Web UI
  • Where to find more information

 Please note, there is also a dedicated webinar on tracking harmonization scheduled for November 26th. 

Register here

 

Introducing the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app

The ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app has been introduced for both shippers and carriers.

It supports shippers in gaining visibility into shipment execution and in managing freight activities with flexible event intake options, while enabling carriers to report events via Web UI, while still leveraging the existing API or EDI options for automated reporting. The app also allows shippers to report events on behalf of their carrier. All events are displayed in a unified view, independent of the submission channel.

Shippers can view carrier milestones (regardless of how the event was received), report planned and unplanned events, provide estimates or delays, view event history, and access attachments.  This allows all of the stakeholders associated with the shipper to stay informed, when a tracking update is made by the shipper themselves. 

Carriers can report milestones and events (planned or unplanned), provide estimates or delays, and view event history, independent of reporter or channel.  Manual reporting through the new app gives carriers an option, in addition to automated reporting through the existing API and EDI, to report events and stay n sync with shipment execution. 

The following screens illustrate the carrier view.

Figure 1: Main view, filter section and worklist

 Figure 2: Detail view, header and tabs

 

Figure 3: Report planned event from header

 

Figure 4: Report unplanned event

 Figure 5: View event history

 

Figure 6: Detailed event overview

 

This carrier how-to video describes the app in detail.

The shipper view and use of the app differ only in minor aspects; more details are available here.

Shippers currently operating with the ‘Track Freight Movement’ app and carriers operating with the ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ app are encouraged to commence adoption of the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app, with ample time to adopt prior to conclusion of the legacy apps in May 2026.

 

Use-case differentiation for event tracking in FC and GTT

As noted earlier, we have introduced a shared application for event reporting, while maintaining the existing API and EDI options for automated reporting. While supporting these options for  tracking data reporting, we can clarify the use-cases and tracking scenarios between FC and GTT.

Going forward, FC will continue to support collaboration between shipper and carrier for contracting, settlement, and dock appointment scheduling. For tracking, FC provides basic milestone event tracking, document attachments, and ETA updates.

GTT supports the same basic tracking as FC, along with more advanced shipment and order-fulfillment tracking scenarios, including geolocation updates, map view, and emissions data, for shipments in the context of the purchase order, sales order, or stock transfer order to which the shipment pertains.  

The graphic below illustrates the differentiation of use cases when using the “Manage Freight Execution” app.

 

In FC, carriers or visibility providers can report milestones and ETAs for road and ocean transports via the web UI or API. Events reported by warehouse or gate operators are included in the ’Manage Freight Execution‘ app. FC shippers can view the events in the event history.

In GTT, data contributors—visibility providers and carriers—can directly report milestones, ETAs, and geolocation updates via API, for shipper’s information and use in the existing ’Track Shipments‘ app. Carriers can now also report events via the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ web UI, sharing specifically milestones, ETAs and documents. Reporting stays in sync between the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ and ‘Track Shipments’ apps.

Synchronization with the S/4HANA remains unchanged for both FC and GTT.

 

Next steps for shippers / solution owners

FC shippers using basic tracking

With this release, we deliver enhanced consistency to improve data reliability and alignment across the landscape. Carriers and shippers can report milestones, ETA, as well as unplanned events via the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app in the web UI, ensuring timely and comprehensive event reporting. In addition, ocean freight tracking is now available, extending visibility to sea shipments and enabling end-to-end tracking.

Please consider the following enablement steps

  1. Notify business users about the new application and update role collections. Admins should either create a new role collection or add the role templates 'ManualReportingDisplayTemplate' and 'ManualReportingProcessTemplate' to an existing role collection. If added to an existing collection, all users in that collection will gain access to the app; if a new collection is created, assign the relevant users to it.

 

Note: SAP will enhance carriers’ role collections on productive carrier tenants. On test tenants, shippers must update their test carriers’ roles.

2. Start using the new 'Manage Freight Execution' application as soon as possible. The legacy application 'Track Freight Movement' remains available until deprecation.

3. Encourage your carriers to adopt and use the new 'Manage Freight Execution' application.

 

GTT solution owners receiving tracking information through B2B connectivity with data contributors

Functional enhancement from this release does not impact their current use case – no changes or next steps required.

 

GTT solution owners planning to request event reporting via Web UI from some data contributors and FC shippers wanting to leveraging advanced tracking

GTT solution owners who want carriers to report events via the web UI can now use the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app. Events submitted through the web UI are visible in the existing  ‘Track Shipments’ app.

Going forward, the map view, geolocation reporting, are no longer available in FC. GTT is SAP’s solution for advanced tracking and order-fulfillment monitoring across sales, purchase, and stock transfer orders, inbound advance ship notices (ASNs), and outbound deliveries. In addition to road and ocean tracking, it supports air and parcel tracking; impact analysis for late or delayed shipments; emissions tracking; and provides a flexible UI and event-to-action scripting for automated alerts and notifications. Further, GTT tracking is not only based on freight order and freight booking level. GTT  can also generate tracking units based on freight orders or freight bookings, based on freight units or containers. GTT is both tightly integrated with SAP S/4HANA and able to be connected to non-SAP applications.

Please consider the following enablement steps (for GTT solution owners only steps 5 and 6):

  1. Subscribe to SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace and onboard.
  2. Decide how you want your freight documents to be tracked in GTTOption 1: Standard IDOC (recommend; Advantage: support advanced tracking, including FU, multiple tracking units (e.g. containers), events reported from S/4, customized events reporting, but requires additional configuration). For more details, see using standard extractor codesOption 2: SOAP message (TransportationOrderGenericTrackedProcessRequest_Out) for TM freight order/booking in GTT (routing request can be entered via customer ticket, component SBN-LBN-INT). Less effort if you are already using this SOAP message for Track Freight Movement app, but limited scope, e.g. only FO and FB with one tracked object (e.g. 1 container per shipment).  
  3. Replicate location from S/4HANA to Location master of BN4L
  4. Maintain system ID and logical system ID in ‘System Connection’ app (see screenshot) 

      5. (Visibility Provider integration – no GTT configuration required, but double check on tracking information in each      shipment e.g. carrier reference, carrier identifier, tracked object, …     

     6. Setup carrier manual reporting via WebUI

  • Invite carriers to onboard via Carrier Onboarding Guide (Note: Please contact your SAP network services lead to guide with aligning the carrier LBN ID and carrier identifier, e.g. SCAC code to leverage Visibility Provider service. Or Maintain Alternate ID in Custom Header of ‘Configure Partner Connection’ app by entering “LBN_CUSTOM_CARRIER_ALT_ID” as Key and “SCAC#1234” as value)
  • Maintain carrier’s LBN ID in business partner master, e.g. update Business' Partner LBN ID in S/4HANA
  • Maintain carrier LBN IDs in carrierListForManageFreightExecution value in Event-to-Action Script in gttft1 model

  • To process events in the same way as in the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app, you must set event status to be triggered by actual technical timestamp in the ‘Manage Models’ app - see Edit the Tracked Process

  •  Adjust entries in ‘Configure Partner Connections’ app e.g, previously maintained “SCAC#1234” should be replaced by the LBN ID - see 'Create Partner Connection’

     7. Get shipper ready to work with ‘Manage Freight Execution app’

  • The admin users need to either create new role collection or add the new roles templates ‘ManualReportingDisplayTemplate’ and ‘ManualReportingProcessTemplate’ to existing role collections. If added to existing role collection, then the users in that role collection will have access to the app. If a new role collection is created, then the users should be added to that role collection.

 

Next steps for carriers / data contributors

Carriers using the legacy Freight Orders for Reporting app

Carriers currently using the ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ app should start using the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app as soon as possible, leaving ample time for adoption before deprecation in May 2026.

Detailed how-to video for carriers on how to use the app can be found here.

 

Carriers or data contributors connecting via API or EDI

For carriers and data contributors currently reporting via API or EDI, there are no changes.

 

Carriers newly requested by their shipper customers to report events via the Web UI

Carriers without an active account in SAP Business Network for Logistics will receive an invitation from their shipper or solution owner to join the network. A detailed guide to activating the account after receiving an invitation is available here.

Further, shippers or solution owners need to notify their carriers if they want them to report via the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app. The carrier’s administrator must assign the necessary roles in the ‘User Management’ app and inform the relevant business users.

A step-by-step tutorial video for carriers on using the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app is available here.

 

Where to find more information

Below, please find a collection of useful links related to the tracking harmonization enhancements from this release.

 

In addition, I would like to point you to our upcoming webcast on November 26th, 10 am CET where you can hear directly from our experts and ask questions – register here

 

SAP Help Portal – What’s New

Feature detail deck on tracking harmonization

Carrier how-to video on ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app

SAP Business Network Freight Execution L2

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace L2

Getting started with SAP Business Network for Logistics

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The above summarizes tracking harmonization as part of the 2511 release. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2511 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: SAP SD Rebates migration to SAP S4 HANA Settlement Ma...
entry.content:
It is technically possible to migrate closed rebate agreements and settlement documents from ECC to S/4HANA, but it is not supported by standard conversion tools. SAP’s recommended practice is to migrate only open agreements and use archiving/reporting for closed ones. If the client insists, you will need a custom migration approach or specialized data migration tools, since S/4HANA has replaced classic rebate processing with Settlement Management (Condition Contracts)

My recommendations would be

  • If audit access is the only driver → Use archiving/reporting (best practice).
  • If client insists on full migration → Develop a custom conversion program to map ECC rebate agreements into S/4HANA condition contracts, with settlement history stored for reference.
  • Tools: SAP Migration Cockpit can handle billing documents, but rebate agreements/settlements will require custom ETL or ABAP programs.


Below would be some Key Considerations

  • Audit compliance: Ensure migrated data is clearly marked as “historical” so it doesn’t interfere with live rebate processing.
  • Data volume: 10 years of billing + rebates is heavy; performance and storage must be planned.
  • Reconciliation: You’ll need to prove that migrated settlement values match ECC records.
  • Effort vs. benefit: Custom migration adds cost and complexity; weigh against simpler archive/reporting solutions.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic value for @title annotation - is it possible?
entry.content:
Hey, there is no official solution, but I guess it's possible to implement some hacks. Proceed at your own risk.

So as you noted it's not really possible to use other JSONModels.  The source must be a ResourceModel. 

So what you could do is creating a second ResourceModel (to keep the original ResourceModel hack free) (could be named i18nDyn or similar) in the manifest.json and also a new folder (i18nDyn) with properties files in each language (i18nDyn_de.properties etc). It should contain the label keys which you reference in your annotation.

E.g. add an annotation country @title: '{i18nDyn>country}' (uses the new ResourceModel) to your data and add a line country=DUMMY to your i18nDyn.properties file.

Now here comes the ugly part: Replace the DUMMY values with actual dynamic values. To do so implement a lifecycle hook (like onInit) in your controller or Component and add the following code

const bundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel('i18nDyn').getResourceBundle();
// access private properties of bundle. ugly and dangerous!
const properties = bundle.aPropertyFiles[0].mProperties;
// modify the values of the keys
properties.country = "Germany";
// now "country" is not "DUMMY" anymore

 This should then work in p13n dialogs as well as regular tables and filter bars.

entry.title: Re: Query on Replenishment strategy in storage type
entry.content:
When you trigger replenishment, the system creates a replenishment request (essentially a requirement). The request quantity is calculated based on the bin’s stock at that moment (0 → max 200 in your example). If you don’t choose Immediate WT Creation, the request sits in the queue until you later create the WT.

This setting tells the system: when creating the WT, recalculate the required quantity based on current stock in the bin. However, this recalculation only works if the replenishment request is flagged to allow adjustment. In practice, EWM often does not reduce the WT quantity if you’ve already manually changed the bin stock, because the replenishment request is still for 200 units. The system assumes the request is valid and creates a WT to fulfill it.

Having said that why you saw 200 instead of 150 is because, the replenishment request was created for 200 units when the bin was empty. Even though you manually put away 50 units, the request itself was not updated. At WT creation, the system still honored the original request quantity. The “New Quantity at WT Creation” setting doesn’t override the request — it only recalculates if the request type and strategy allow dynamic adjustment.

So check the below areas

In customizing under Activate Replenishment Strategies, check if the strategy allows recalculation at WT creation. Some strategies like planned vs. automatic behave differently.

Verify whether the request is set to be “flexible” or “fixed.” If fixed, the WT will always match the request quantity.

Ensure that the stock check at WT creation is active. In some versions, this requires additional customizing in the replenishment control parameters.

entry.title: Re: Story of SAP Materials Management Module in Implementation Projects
entry.content:
It is a nice story. However somehow biased. You focus mainly on the purchasing process. In my opinion what MM is all about is inventory management, i.e. inventory planning and controlling. In other words making sure we stock what is needed but no more than that. Having said that, in my opinion the heart of MM is inventory controlling and document analysis reports and above all MRP planning and MRP exceptions.

If you focus on purchasing only, you lose all the automation that SAP provides. Purchases need to be plan manually outside of the system and ERP becomes an overpriced cash register - transactions are just registered there while management is still done in spreadsheets.

entry.title: Re: The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code
entry.content:
@MattHarding I believe these "single action per file" controllers created by the guided development do more harm than good. Maybe you should refactor this to a real controller (extension). 

Name of the file is now Something.controller.js (and not Something.js)

sap.ui.define([
    'sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension'
], function (ControllerExtension, MessageBox) {
    'use strict';

    return ControllerExtension.extend('provide.real.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt', {
        // this section allows to extend lifecycle hooks or hooks provided by Fiori elements
        override: {
            onInit: function () {
                // blabla
            }
        },

        onPressRefresh: function (oContext, aSelectedContexts) {
            this.base.getExtensionAPI().refresh();
        }
    });
});

This way you have a real instance of something class like, you can access instance variables, this works as expected etc. 

You can generate these controller extensions using the page map. After that if you create a custom action using guided development and pass the extension file name to the guide it will add the new method at the correct place in your controller extension.

To invoke these handlers from the manifest you have to use a little different syntax though.

"actions": {
    "print": {
        "press": ".extension.provide.real.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt.onPressPrint",
        "visible": true,
        "enabled": true,
        "requiresSelection": false,
        "text": "{@i18n>print}"
    }
}

 The full namespace to the method PLUS ".extension." as a prefix.

Also the controller extension needs to be declared in the manifest, but the page map should handle this for you. If not:

"extends": {
  "extensions": {
    "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
      "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
        "controllerName": "provide.read.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt"
      }
    }
  }
}

entry.title: Applying User Filters in SAP Identity Provisioning Service to Sync a Single User from MS Entra ID
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

I’m writing this blog after going through extensive SAP documentation and community articles. The purpose of this post is to explain how to apply a user filter in the SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) so that only a single user gets synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID.

 

🔧Requirement

We want to sync only one specific user from Microsoft Entra ID into the target system using IPS by applying a user-level filter on the source system.

 

📌Prerequisites

Before starting, you should have:

  • A Source System of type Microsoft Entra ID (or any other user-store source system)

  • A Target System of type Identity Authentication
    (You can choose a different target system depending on your requirement)

These systems must be configured in your SAP BTP Cloud Identity Services.

 

🔍Analysis

When we first executed the job in Simulation Mode, we found that our Entra ID environment contained 5000+ users. Running a full sync would have immediately written all these users into the target system—which we wanted to avoid until we were confident.

To prevent syncing the entire user base, we decided to use the user filter property in the source system configuration.

This led us to applying a filter that would sync only one specific user, allowing us to validate the job behavior safely.

 

✅Solution

Below is the property you need to configure in the Source System to sync only a single user from Entra ID (or any similar source system):

Property Name

aad.user.filter

Property Value

userPrincipalName eq 'rgera@company.com'

This filter ensures that only the user with the specified User Principal Name is retrieved and synchronized.

Refer to the screenshot in your Cloud Identity Service configuration for guidance.

 

🧪 Result

After saving the property and running the job again, only one user was successfully synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID—exactly as expected.

 

📘Additional Notes

IPS supports many different filter conditions. You can adapt filters based on:

  • givenName

  • mail

  • displayName

  • objectId

  • Group conditions

  • And more…

These filters help you fine-tune user synchronization based on your business needs.

 

🤝Conclusion

I hope this blog helps anyone looking to apply user-level filters when running synchronization jobs in SAP Identity Provisioning Service. It’s a simple yet powerful way to limit and control the data flowing between systems—especially in large environments.

Regards,
Rohit Gera

entry.title: Parked Supplier Invoices Only Show Vendor Line (No G/L or Cost Object Lines) in FI Apps
entry.content:
When creating a supplier invoice in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and saving it as complete (parked), the system only displays the vendor line item in FI apps such as Manage Journal Entries, Manage Supplier Line Items, or any of the parked-document CDS views (I_ParkedOplAcctgDocument, I_ParkedOplAcctgDocGLItem, VBSEG*-based views).

The offsetting G/L account line and its cost-object assignment (cost center, WBS, etc.)—which are visible in the Create Supplier Invoice app—do not appear anywhere on the FI side while the invoice is parked. This behaviour differs from parked G/L journal entries (e.g., document type SA), where both debit and credit lines are visible immediately.

Customers often expect a full accounting preview of the parked supplier invoice in FI apps, especially when using approval workflows or during UAT. However, parked RE invoices are stored as MM parked invoice documents, and at this stage no FI document with full accounting lines exists yet. Only the vendor line is created as a parked FI item.

The complete accounting document (vendor + G/L + cost objects) is only generated after the invoice is posted, meaning FI reporting apps and CDS views cannot display the missing G/L or cost-object information during the parked phase.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics– Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let’s clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company → Product Category → Product → Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  → Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  → Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  → Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  → Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy 🔗 Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy 🔗Not supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy – For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy – For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy – For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy – For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies – For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

👉When you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent–child links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent–Child Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent–child works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region → Country → City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel → Country → City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC

entry.title: Source-Side Filtering vs. Dynamic Topics &Filtering with SAP Advanced Event Mesh and ASAPIO Addon
entry.content:
As more and more organizations modernize their integration landscapes whether they are SAP or non-SAP eco systems, Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming an essential approach to achieving real-time, scalable, and loosely coupled data exchange. Traditional master data distribution—often based on scheduled or API-driven replication—can no longer keep up with the dynamic needs of digital ecosystems that demand instant synchronization across hybrid SAP and non-SAP environments.

By leveraging SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), and ERP event-on for AEM, enterprises can easily shift toward event-based master data distribution to ensure that updates in systems of records are propagated intelligently, only where and when they are needed. This trend not only reduces system load and redundancy but also enables fine-grained control through mechanisms like source-side filtering and dynamic topic filtering within brokers, which together make EDA a cornerstone for next-generation integration strategies.

Three years ago, I shared a blog on the SAP Event Enablement Add-On for SAP Event Mesh. Since then, SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) has rapidly gained growth as an enterprise-grade event broker with the capability to connect applications, data, and devices across diverse landscapes. 

In this blog, I would like to revisit the ASAPIO Add-On, specifically in the context of integration SAP Advanced Event Mesh. While the add-on continues to be powered by ASAPIO technology, its usage patterns and relevance have evolved alongside AEM's growing adoption. Most of the functionalities are similar but with the ability to build custom payloads and to connect to AEM, it unlocks the value of moving data in real-time from large to very large use cases.

@Benedikt_Sprung   has already published an excellent step-by-step guide on setting up and using the add-on with AEM. Instead of duplicating that content, my focus here will be on a key design consideration: the filtering options available with the add-on and AEM and how they can be applied effectively in real-world scenarios. 

 

Why filtering matters?

Typically, Event-driven architectures (EDA) topics define how events are organized. The way we design and manage topics has a profound impact on scalability, governance, and maintainability. 

In the context of SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with ASAPIO add-on, two patterns come into discussion with event filtering: source-side filtering (on sender SAP applications) and Dynamic Topics & Filtering (within AEM brokers).

This post explores the difference between these two approaches, when to use each, and how AEM enables more intelligent event distribution in enterprise landscapes.

 

Option 1: Source-Side Filtering on Event Producer

Source-Side filtering usually means the producer (event source) decides dynamically at publish time whether an event should be triggered. Often, a filter based on payload data will be applied to the event liberation.

With ASAPIO add-on, you can use a check function module in header attributes to filter on attributes of the Business Object. For example, you can add the Attribute ID to your Header Attribute customizing in event add-on for ERP: BOR_ATTRIBUTE_<BOR Attribute from SWO1>

 

In this case, only the material data with material group 004 will be triggered. The event broker (AEM) will not receive any data outside of material group 004.

Option 2: Dynamic Topics & Filtering on Event Broker

With this option, the producer (event source) decides at publish time which topic an event should be sent to. Often, topic names are built using runtime data (e.g., customer ID, region, product type).

With ASAPIO add-on, you can set up dynamic topics easily with Field Mapping. It helps you define different layers of the topics and make dynamic filtering easier later during consumption.

 

Based on event context, events can be published to different topics into SAP AEM. Consumers then subscribe only to the events they care about. In above example, topics are built dynamically with the Sales Org ID. If a consumer wants all the data of Sales Order update of Org 1000, it can subscribe to topic /UPDATE/V1/JSON/sap-bo-event/ERD100/1000/BUS2032/>.

In this case, all events are still published to the broker but they can be sorted/routef based on the structure of the topics.

 

When to Use Which?

Source Side Filtering typically works well when consumers are highly specialized and fixed. You don't expect new applications to be added in the future. And in the case when broker load and network traffic is a concern, you can use this option to reduce overhead.

In contrast, dynamic topics & filtering helps you operate at enterprise scale (hundreds of apps, regions, business lines). You want to use this option when you want producers to stay simple and consumers to self-serve. with SAP AEM, it can support very large scale use cases. Using this option will help you have better governance and discoverability on events. 

Dynamic topics & filtering is recommended in most of the use cases as it supports better scalability and flexibility in an EDA integration. To support this option, SAP AEM has its Smart Topics feature to organize event topics. The Topic Taxonomy can be described with none+verb+properties. AEM relies on hierarchical topic structures(using  “/” separators) to enable dynamic routing, filtering, and fine-tuned subscriptions.

An Example of master data event topics could be:

  • materialmaster / updated / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>
  • materialmaster / created / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>

With a defined structure, subscribers can filter based on dynamic topics that they are interested in:

This allows flexibility of subscription and allows consumers to self-serve as well.

 

Conclusion and key takeaways

While source-side filtering gives flexibility, it often leads to topic sprawl and tighter coupling. With SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, enterprises can adopt Smart Topics with Dynamic Topics & Filtering — a governance-friendly, scalable way to manage events. This approach keeps producers simple and empowers consumers at enterprise scale.

In most of the use cases, master data distribution is a fan-out pattern, in this case Dynamic Topics & Filtering will provide more flexibility to distribute the data based on needs without tight coupling with producers. Below is a reference architecture for a fan-out scenario and with dynamic topic filtering and multiple integration options, you will be able to easily send to the relevant data to consumers.

 

Happy Eventing!!

SAP Integration Suite SAP S/4HANA Event-driven architecture

entry.title: Assertion failed: The installer is started with enabled database environment variables in SWPM
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

I would like to share a knowledge base article regarding the issues while performing Classical Migration using Export/Import method and SWPM tool.

Scenario:

We have an ABAP system for which we have taken export using SWPM on source server and here we are doing an SAP system installation while importing the exported data using SWPM tool (Installation + Migration), it throws below error while import.

Assertion failed: The installer is started with enabled database environment variables, which is not supported

Environment: Windows server 2019

Cause:

This issue occurred because there was already a System on target host with the same SID which was not properly uninstalled and cleaned up, so there were few Sybase database environment variables remained in the target host Registry Editor(regedit) in windows server which was not properly cleaned up during uninstallation.

Solution:

There are two ways in which this issue can be resolved.

  1. The OS level user from which you are running SWPM, if it contains that environment variables and regedit (Registry) entries of old system SID, running SWPM with another user having same privileges fixes the issue.
  2. Remove the environment variables and entries of Old SID from regedit and restart SWPM and try again.

Additional Information:

You might come across a situation where your target system is corrupted, or system failure happens and you may loss the important encrypted data which is copied from source.  

While importing the data, SWPM provides you key id and key value which you need to take a note of and keep it in a safer place.

The secure storage will be encrypted with the following key:

 Key ID:

YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS_<SID>_INSTALLER

 Key Value:

***********************************************

Make a backup of above Key ID and 58-character Key Value and keep it in a secure place for disaster recovery.

When you are in the process of system installation and want to use this system as source for a system copy or system rename, you must provide this backup to restore access to the encrypted data in the copied system.

Thanks & Regards,

Tanmay Gupta

SAP

entry.title: Und dann? - Generative KI erklären mit Snap!GPT
entry.content:
Generative Künstliche Intelligenz (KI) ist momentan in aller Munde. Menschen verwenden Large Language Models (LLMs) regelmäßig in ihrem Alltag. Sie helfen uns, E-Mails zu schreiben oder Urlaube zu planen. Wir benutzen sie als Sparringspartner um unsere Ideen weiterzuentwickeln und mit ihnen gemeinsam zu programmieren. 

Um generative KI in einer produktiven und sinnvollen Art und Weise zu verwenden, ist es wichtig, dass wir ihre grundlegenden Prinzipien, Vorteile und Limitationen verstehen. 

 

Snap!GPT

Einer der wichtigsten Mechanismen in diesen Systemen ist die sogenannte Next Token Prediction, also die Vorhersage des wahrscheinlichsten nächsten Worts oder "Tokens" in einer Sequenz  basierend auf dem vorherigen Text und mithilfe statistischer Sprachmodelle.  

Die folgenden Materialien erklären das Konzept eines statistischen Sprachmodells und einer Next Token Prediction anhand von 30 Märchen der Gebrüder Grimm: 

  • Paper “Snap!GPT – Bausteine für generative Künstliche Intelligenz" (IBIS):
    https://www.informatischebildung.de/index.php/ibis/article/view/31 
  • Starter-Projekt mit allen benötigten Blöcken: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/project?username=jadga&projectname=SnapGPT%20%2d%20MW 
  • Lösungsprojekt (mit Musik-Skripten und Stift-Objekt):
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=SnapGPT%20%2d%20IBIS&editMode&noRun 
  • Video (EN):
    https://www.youtube.com/live/0ft0J3rh3WY?t=1971s  

 

Worteinbettungen (Word Embeddings)

Obwohl dieses Modell grammatikalisch korrekte Sätze bilden kann, ist es offensichtlich nicht besonders nah an modernen LLMs. Diese benötigen Monate von Training mit einem Korpus so groß wie das gesamte Internet und statistischen Modellen, die Billionen von Token enthalten. 

Zudem arbeiten moderne LLMs in der Trainingsphase mit mehreren neuronalen Netzen,  die numerische Eingaben brauchen. Deshalb werden sogenannte Worteinbettungen (Word Embeddings) verwendet, in denen Wörter und Ausdrücke als Vektoren repräsentiert sind. 

In diesem Projekt kannst du mit einem kleinen Set von Worteinbettungen experimentieren. Es enthält ca. 20 000 Wörter und ihre jeweilige Vektorrepräsentation. Jeder Vektor hat 300 Dimensionen, die Features genannt werden. In Snap! wird das als eine Liste mit 300 Elementen ausgedrückt, jedes Element ist eine Dezimalzahl zwischen -1 und 1). 

Die Orientierung der Wörter und ihre Abstände und Verhältnisse zueinander codieren ihre Semantik. In anderen Worten, Vektoren, die nahe beinander liegen stehen für Synonyme oder ähnliche Wörter,  die Vektoren von Wörtern mit sehr unterschiedlicher Bedeutung haben einen großen Abstand zueinander. 

Die 300 Features der Vektoren der Wörter "dog" (blau) und "tree" (pink) übereinander geplottet.

  • Link zum Projekt Worteinbettungen: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/project?username=jadga&projectname=Worteinbettung%20%2d%20DE 
    (Das Projekt ist adaptiert von ecraft2learn, Ken Kahn, Universität Oxford (https://ecraft2learn.github.io/ai/))

 

Über den Transformer

Moderne LLMs nutzen eine sogenannte Transformer-Architektur (GPT steht für generative pre-trained transformer) - zwei neuronale Netze (NN), die zusammenarbeiten.

Grober Überblick über die Transformer-Architektur. Eingaben (I) werden an das Encoder Neural Network gegeben und dort in verarbeitbare Einheiten umgewandelt. Die Ergebnisse werden an das Decoder Neural Network übergeben, das dann eine neue Ausgabe (O) generieren kann.

 

Encoder

Die Texteingabe wird in einzelne Einheiten aufgeteilt (Tokenisierung), bevor sie an das Encoder NN übergeben werden. Dort werden die Token als Vektoren (Worteinbettung) codiert. 

Der Satz "Alonzo isst ein Gummibärchen" enthält 4 Token. Jedem dieser Token wird ein Vektor zugewiesen im ersten Schritt der Codierung im Encoder Neural Network.

Würden nur Worteinbettungen verwendet, würden die beiden folgenden Sätze dieselben Vektoren enthalten und dadurch gleich codiert werden, obwohl sie sehr unterschiedliche Bedeutungen haben: 

Alonzo isst ein Gummibärchen.  vs.  Ein Gummbärchen isst Alonzo. 

Die Positions-Codierung stellt sicher, dass das nicht passiert. Ein individueller Positionsvektor wird jedem Token in der Sequenz zugewiesen, um die Übersicht über die Reihenfolge der Wörter in einem Satz zu behalten. 

 

Einige Wörter erhalten ihre Bedeutung aus dem Kontext eines Satzes. Beispielsweise kann das Wort "Bank" mehrere Bedeutungen haben; die passende kann aus den umgebenden Wörtern im Satz abgeleitet werden. Enthält der Satz zum Beispiel zusätzlich die Wörter "Überweisung", "Geld" oder "sparen", können wir davon ausgehen, dass das Finanzinstitut gemeint ist. Sind die anderen Wörter "sitzen", "Park" oder "Erholung", ist die Bedeutung wohl eher Sitzgelegenheit. 

Einige Wörter haben ohne Bezugswörter in einer Sequenz kaum eine eigene Bedeutung. Pronomina wie "sie" beispielsweise erlangen ihre Bedeutung von den Wörtern, auf die sie sich beziehen. 

Der Self-Attention Vektor wird vom Encoder NN berechnet, um die Beziehung von jedem Token in einer Sequenz zu jedem anderen Token in dieser Sequenz darzustellen. In anderen Worten legt er fest, inwieweit die anderen Wörter eines Satzes zur Bedeutung eines bestimmten Wortes beitragen. 

Alonzo and seine Freund:innen haben Gummibärchen. Er isst sie gerne.

In diesem Fall könnte sich das Wort "sie" auf Gummibärchen (wahrscheinlicher) oder seine Freund:innen (weniger wahrscheinlich) beziehen. Der Self-Attention Vektor in diesem Fall wird einen hohen Ähnlichkeitswert (Similarity Score) zwischen den Wörtern "Gummibärchen" und "sie" aufweisen.

 

Decoder

Die Ausgabe des Encoder NNs (Worteinbettung, Positionscodierung, Self-Attention Vektor) wird an das Decoder Neuronale Netz gefüttert, das die tatsächliche Vorhersage des nächsten Tokens übernimmt. 

Um das Decoder NN zu trainieren, wird ein Prozess, der als Maskierung bezeichnet wird, genutzt. 
Der Decoder erhält eine bekannte Eingabe, in der bestimmte Wörter versteckt (maskiert) wurden, und muss diese maskierten Wörter vorhersagen. Falls er den falschen Token vorhersagt, werden die Gewichte des neuronalen Netzes so lange angepasst, bis der Decoder den wahrscheinlichsten nächsten Token korrekt vorhersagen kann. 

Hier ist eine vertiefte und mathematischere Erklärung darüber, wie Transformer genau funktionieren (auf Englisch): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zxQyTK8quyY

 

Weitere Materialien:

ELIZA:

Frühe Chatbots wie ELIZA von Joseph Weizenbaum (1964) nutzen einen anderen, nicht-statistischen Ansatz, um natürliche Sprache zu verarbeiten. Sie imitieren menschliche Konversationen, indem sie Sprachmuster erkennen und auf diese mit vordefinierten Teilantworten reagieren. Die DOCTOR Version von ELIZA beispielsweise simuliert Konversationen basierend auf der Idee von Therapeut:innen, die kontinuierlich Rückfragen stellen bezugnehmend auf die ursprüngliche Eingabe der Nutzer:innen. 

Diese Version von ELIZA versucht Muster zu identifizieren und Rückfragen basierend auf diesen Mustern und bezugnehmend auf die Eingabe der Nutzer:innen zu geben

  • Teste diese Snap! Implementierung von ELIZA und versuche Unterschiede zur statistischen Next-Token Prediction zu identifizieren: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=Eliza%202023&editMode&noR...

 

GPT unplugged:

Menschen sind verhältnismäßig gut darin, nächste Tokens vorherzusagen; unsere Fähigkeit hängt aber stark vom sogenannten Kontextfenster ab, ein Begriff, der auch in LLMs eine Rolle spielt. Das Kontextfenster beschreibt die Anzahl der Tokens, die berücksichtigt werden (können),  um den nächsten Token vorherzusagen. 

In unserem Snap!GPT ist das maximale Kontextfenster 4 Wörter. Moderne LLMs haben Kontextfenster, die aus mehreren tausend Token bestehen können. Mit der folgenden unplugged Aktivität soll das Konzept des Kontextfensters verdeutlicht werden. 

Benötigtes Material: 1 Blatt Papier und ein Stift pro teilnehmender Person.

Alle Teilnehmenden schreiben ein Wort auf ihr jeweiliges Papier und geben es an die nächste Person weiter. In der ersten Runde soll das Kontextfenster (Anzahl der Wörter, die eine Person sieht, bevor sie ihr eigenes Wort anhängt) ein Wort sein. 

Das bedeutet, die nächste Person schreibt ihr Wort unter das vorherige Wort und faltet das Papier so, dass das erste Wort nicht mehr zu sehen ist, nur das Wort, das sie eben hinzugefügt hat. Dann wird das Papier an die nächste Person weitergegeben. Wiederholt diesen Prozess ungefähr 12 Mal. Entfaltet dann die Papiere und lest einige der generierten Sätze laut vor. Versucht den sinnvollsten Satz mit einem Kontextfenster von 1 zu finden. 

Wiederholt dann das ganze Spiel mit einer leichten Adaption. Diesmal schreibt die erste Person 4 Wörter (jedes in eine neue Zeile). Die nächste Person fügt ihr Wort hinzu und faltet das Papier dann so, dass das erste Wort versteckt ist und die anderen 4 Wörter sichtbar bleiben. Wiederholt diesen Prozess ungefähr 10 Mal. Entfaltet dann die Papiere und lest einige Sätze laut vor. Versucht wieder den inhaltlich und grammatikalisch besten Satz zu finden. 

Ergeben die Sätze mehr Sinn, wenn das Kontextfenster größer ist? 
-> Ja, größere Kontextfenster ermöglichen es uns, präziser den nächsten Token vorherzusagen. Dadurch können entweder über semantische oder statistische Methoden grammatikalisch bessere Sätze gebildet werden (z.B. Subjekt, Prädikat, Objekt Struktur, Einleitung von Nebensätzen,...)

Machen wir Menschen das wie ein LLM Sprache generiert?
-> Nein, wir arbeiten mit syntaktischem und semantischem Verständnis von Sprache, nicht mit statistischen Modellen. Menschen arbeiten mit Sprachmustern (Grammatik) und können aus wenigen Beispielen lernen, ähnliche Sätze zu bilden, LLMs benötigen große Mengen von Trainingsdaten, um Token basierend auf ihren statistischen Modellen vorherzusagen.

Auf der linken Seite ist das Ergebnis der unplugged Aktivität mit Kontextfenster 1 zu sehen, es is keine kohärente Satzstruktur erkennbar. Das Papier auf der rechten Seite zeigt das Ergebnis der Aktivität mit Kontextfenster 4. Hier sind Satz-(Sub-)Strukturen vorhanden. 

SoekiaGPT:

Ein didaktisches Sprachmodell entwickelt von Michael Hielscher (PH Schwyz) und die Inspiration für Snap!GPT. SoekiaGPT möchte ebenfalls das Prinzip der Next Token Prediction von LLMs basierend auf Märchen (und Wetterberichten) erfahrbar machen:
https://www.soekia.ch/GPT/ 

 

Snap!GPT Mal-App:

Mit dieser Snap!GPT Mal-App kann basierend auf Richtungen des nächsten Liniensegments Gekritzel generiert werden. Der Input, der als Grundlage für das statistische Modell genutzt wird, wird selbst von Benutzer:innen gezeichnet.

Diese Aktivität kann als Einstieg für eine Diskussion über gute Einstiegszeichnungen verwendet werden. Warum ist es schwer, geschlossene Strukturen zu generieren? Warum ist das Programm in der Lage, buchstaben-ähnliche Strukturen zu erzeugen, aber keinen tatsächlichen Text?

Eingabe für die Snap!GPT Kritzel-App, Ergebnis nach 2000 Wiederholungen der Next Token Prediction und eine Sammlung aller Ergebnisse eines Workshops

  • Teste die Mal-App unter: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=bromagosa&ProjectName=Drawing%20AI&embedMo...

entry.title: What’s next? – Generative AI with Snap!GPT
entry.content:
Generative AI is everywhere right now. People incorporate Large Language Models (LLMs) in their daily routines, they help us write e-mails and plan our trips, we use them as sparring partners to pitch our ideas or develop code together with them.

In order to use generative AI in a productive and meaningful way, it is important that we understand its underlying principles, advantages and especially limitations.

 

Snap!GPT

One of the major mechanisms in those systems is what we call next token prediction – based on preceding text, the most probable next word or “token” in a sequence is selected with the help of statistical language models.

The following resources aim to explain the concept of statistical language models and next token prediction with 30 fairy tales of the brothers Grimm:

  • Paper “Snap!GPT – Building blocks for generative AI”:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/d7aqWvd?rc=10&doi=SAP1257583
  • Starter Project with all required blocks: https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=SnapGPT%20%2d%20MW%20%2d%20EN&editMode&noRun
  • Solution Project (containing music script and pen sprite):
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=SnapGPT-Microworld-IBIS-EN-Solution
  • Video:
    https://www.youtube.com/live/0ft0J3rh3WY?t=1971s  

 

Word Embeddings

Obviously, although only generating grammatically correct sentences, this isn’t anywhere close to a modern LLM. They require months of training with a corpus as large as the whole internet and their statistical models contain trillions of tokens.

Additionally, modern LLMs include several neural networks in their pre-training that require numerical values. Therefore, they use so-called word embeddings, vector representations of words and expressions.

In this project you can explore a small set of word embeddings. It contains about 20 000 words and their vector representations. Each vector has 300 dimensions (in Snap! that is expressed as a list with 300 items, each item is a decimal number between -1 and 1).

The arrangement of words and their distances and relations encode their semantics. In other words, vectors with a small distance represent synonyms or closely related words, words with very different meanings also have very different vectors.

The 300 features of the vectors of the words "dog" (blue) and "tree" (pink) plotted on top of each other .

 

  • Link to the word-embeddings project: https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=word%20average-EN
    (The project is adapted from ecraft2learn by Ken Kahn from the University of Oxford (https://ecraft2learn.github.io/ai/))

 

About the Transformer

Modern LLMs use a transformer architecture (GPT stands for generative pre-trained transformer), two neural networks working together.

very rough overview of the Transformer architecture. The input is given to the Encoder Neural Network whose results are used by the Decoder Neural Network to generate new output.

The text input is split into individual tokens (tokenization) before it’s given to the Encoder Neural Network where the tokens are encoded in vectors (word embeddings).

The sentence "Alonzo eats a gummy bear" contains 4 tokens. Each of them is assigned a vector in the first step of the encoding in the Encoder Neural Network

Using just word embeddings, the following two sentences will result in the same vectors although they have a very different meaning: 

Alonzo eats a gummy bear.  vs.  A gummy bear eats Alonzo. 

The positional encoding takes care of that. 
A positional vector is assigned to every word to keep track of the order of words in a sentence.

 

For some words, their meaning depends on the context of the sentence. The word “bank” for example, can have different meanings, which can be inferred from other words around it. Does the sentence e.g. contain the words “deposit”, “money” or “wire transfer”, we’re probably talking about the financial institution. Are the other words “lake”, “water” or “fish” it’s more likely that the word “bank” in this case means riverside.

Some words only get their meaning from other words in a sequence. Pronouns like “them” for example obtain their meaning from the word they are referring to.

Alonzo and his friends are having gummy bears. He likes eating them.

The self-attention vector is calculated by the Encoder Neural Network to encode the relationship of a token in a sequence with all other tokens in that sequence. It establishes to what extent other words in a sentence contribute to the meaning of a certain word. In this case, the word “them” could refer to gummy bears (more likely) or his friends (less likely), the self attention vector in this case would have a high similarity score for the words “gummy bears” and “them”.

 

The output of the Encoder Neural Network is fed into the Decoder Neural Network which is performing the actual next token prediction. 
To train the Decoder Neural Network, a process called Masking is used. The Decoder is given a known input in which certain words were hidden (masked) and has to predict those masked words. If it guesses the wrong token, the weights are adjusted until the Decoder can predict the most likely next token correctly.

Here’s a more mathematical and in depth explanation of how transformers work: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zxQyTK8quyY

 

Further resources:

ELIZA:

Early chatbots like Joseph Weizenbaum’s ELIZA (1964) used a different, non-statistical approach to Natural Language Processing (NLP). They were programmed to mimic a human conversational parter by recognizing language patterns and reacting to them in a predefined way. The DOCTOR version of ELIZA for example was simulating conversations based on the idea of a therapist constantly asking follow-up questions referencing the user’s original input.

This version of ELIZA tries to identify patterns and then asks follow up questions based on these patterns, referring to what the user previously said.

Try this Snap! implementation of ELIZA and try to identify differences to the statistical next-token prediction: https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=Eliza%202023&editMode&noRun

 

GPT unplugged:

Humans are fairly good at predicting next tokens; however our ability highly depends on the context window, a term that also plays a role in LLMs. The context window describes the number of tokens taken into consideration to predict the next one.

In our Snap!GPT, the context window has a maximum of 4 words. Modern LLMs have potential context windows of several thousand tokens.
You can experience the concept of the context window in the following unplugged activity.

Required material: 1 sheet of paper and 1 pen per participating person.

Each participant writes a word on their paper and hands it to the next person. In the first round, the context window (the number of words a person sees before they have to add their word) is one word. That means the next person writes their word under the first word and folds the paper such that the first word isn’t readable anymore, only the word they added. The then paper is handed to the next person. Repeat this process about 12 times. Then unfold the paper and read a couple of generated sentences out loud. Try to find the most reasonable one with a context window of 1.

Then repeat the whole game but this time, the first person writes 4 words (one per row), the next person adds their word and folds the paper so that only the first word is hidden, the other 4 words will stay visible. Repeat this process about 10 times. Then unfold the papers and read the sentences out loud.

Do they make more sense? If yes, why do you think that is the case?
-> Larger context window allows us to make more precise predictions of the next token.

Do we do this the way an LLM does that?
-> No, we work with syntactic and semantic understanding of language, not with statistical models. Humans learn language patterns (grammar) and can form similar sentences from very few examples, LLMs need a huge training base to predict tokens based on their statistical language model.

On the left side you can see the output of the unplugged activity when only seeing the previous word. No coherent sentence or even substructure can be formed. The paper on the right shows the result of a context window of 4 words.

 

SoekiaGPT:

A didactical language model and the basis for Snap!GPT, also exploring the next token prediction concept of LLMs: https://bootstrapworld.org/SoekiaGPT/

Originally developed by Michael Hielscher (PH Schwyz), translated by the bootstrap community.

 

Snap!GPT Drawing App:

This Snap!GPT based drawing app lets you explore the generation of scribbles based on predicting the direction for the next line segment. You will draw an input that is used as a basis for the statistical model and by that will be able to generate custom data for your next-token prediction. This activity can be used to discuss which types of initial sketches are better than others. Why it's very hard to recreate closed shapes. Or why the program is not able to generate actual text but letter-like structures. 

Input for the scribbling Snap!GPT, output 2000 iterations of the next token prediction and a mural with a collection of workshop results.

Try the drawing app at: 
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=bromagosa&ProjectName=Drawing%20AI&embedMode&noExitWarning

entry.title: Re: Why wouldn't a minority indicator populate for every...
entry.content:
Check the following:

  • Purchasing Info Record: Does the minority indicator exist there? If not, the PO line won’t inherit it.
  • Purchasing Org/Plant assignment: Confirm the vendor master minority indicator is maintained consistently across all org levels.
  • Custom logic: Review exits/BAdIs used in PO creation — sometimes the indicator is set only for certain conditions.
  • Field selection: Ensure the field is not suppressed for certain document types or item categories.
